markdownRemark.html:
Score: 100

ajc.com  (WEB - en-US)

The website for The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, a daily newspaper covering Atlanta and the state of Georgia.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

Atlanta Journal-Constitution is the flagship publication owned by Cox Media Group, a subsidiary of Cox Enterprises, a private company that owns four daily newspapers and 14 television stations in the United States.

Cox-owned newspapers generate revenue from advertising and subscriptions to their printed and digital editions.

AJC.com offers a limited number of free articles and then requires a subscription to access additional content. It also runs myAJC.com, which offers paying customers additional access to “in-depth stories, videos, interactive features and topics,” according to a description on the site.

Content

The site publishes text, video, and podcasts. It divides content into categories including News, Politics, Things to do, Life, and Sports. Stories are also grouped by Atlanta-area counties on the County by County page.

AJC.com publishes Politically Georgia, which provides in-depth coverage of state politics. National news is provided by Cox Media Group’s content desk, Gannett newspapers, and The Associated Press. Videos from Channel 2 Action News, a Cox-owned television station in Atlanta, are also embedded in some stories.

Credibility

Most stories on AJC.com are based on original reporting. The site’s reporters break news, interview subjects of stories for comment, and employ measured language. Headlines match the content of stories. Opinion content is marked as such.

AJC.com publishes corrections at the top of stories, indicating what was corrected.

In 2016, the Atlanta Journal-Constitution published an investigative series about physicians continuing to practice medicine after being accused, and sometimes convicted, of sexual misconduct. The series was a finalist for the 2017 Pulitzer Prize in National Reporting.  

Transparency

Articles on the website list the writer responsible for the story. The site maintains a page listing newsroom staff with accompanying contact and biographical information. It also provides email addresses and phone numbers for the company’s leadership team. The site discloses that it is owned by Cox Media Group.

History

The newspaper began in 1868 after the Atlanta Daily Opinion was renamed the The Atlanta Constitution. The Atlanta Journal was founded in 1883. In 1950, James Cox, a former governor of Ohio, purchased the two papers separately and merged their Sunday editions. The two papers’ newsrooms combined in 1982. In 2001 the last Atlanta Journal was published and the paper officially became the current Atlanta Journal-Constitution.  

The paper has won Pulitzer Prizes in local and public service reporting and editorial writing. The most recent was in 1995, for editorial cartooning.

AJC.com began publishing content from the two papers in 1998.

Disclosure: Cox Media is a unit of Cox Enterprises, a minority investor in NewsGuard Technologies, Inc., the owner of NewsGuard.

Written by:
Joe Danielewicz

Edited by:
Josh Keefe Eric Effron
